The Solution Class¶

class ionize.Solution(ions=, []concentrations=, []T=25)¶

Represent a solution containing a set of ions.

Initialize with solution(ions, concentrations), where ions is a list containing AspPy ion objects, and concentrations is a list containing positive scalars. Can also take T as an optional temperature argument, in Celcius.

When a new solution is initialized, it will immediately calculate the equilibrium state, including the pH and the ionic strength (I) of the solution. These values willl be stored as permenant attributes of the object. Other solution properties can be calculated by invoking the appropriate method.

See also Ion.

H_conductivity(obj)¶

Return the conductivity of protons in solution.

Corrects for the mobility of the ion using the ion object’s actual mobility.

Kw_eff(obj, I=None)¶

Return the effective water dissociation constant.

Based on the activity corrections to H+ and OH-.

OH_conductivity(obj)¶

Return the conductivity of hydroxyls in solution.

Corrects for the mobility of the ion using the ion object’s actual mobility.

alberty()¶

Return the Alberty conservation function value of a solution.

Throw a warning if the ions are not univalent, or if water dissociation cannot be neglected.

buffering_capacity(obj)¶

Return the buffering capacity of the solution.

This function generates an approximate solution to the buffering capacity by finding the derivative of the pH with respect to the addition of an acid insult at small concentration.

cH(obj, pH=None, I=None)¶

Return the concentration of protons in solution.

cOH(obj, pH=None, I=None)¶

Return the concentration of hydroxyls in solution.

calc_I(obj, pH, I_guess=0)¶

Return an estimate of the ionic strength of the solution.

calc_I should only be used during solution initialization. After that, the equilibrium ionic strength is stored in obj.I.

pH must be supplied. If a guess for ionic strength is not supplied, ionic strength corrections will not be used.

calc_pH(obj, I=0)¶

Return the pH of the object.

If an ionic strength is specified, uses the corrected acidity constants. This function should be used only when finding the equilibrium state. After that, the value should be pulled from obj.pH.

If ionic strength does not exist, assume it is zero. This function is used to find the equilibrium state, so it cannot pull the ionic strength from the object.

conductivity(obj)¶

Return the electrical conductivity of the solution.

Relies on molar conductivity calculations from ion and total conductivity of H+ and OH-.

The conductivity is returned in Seimens per meter.

dielectric(obj, T=25)¶

Return the dielectric constant of water at a specified temperature.

The temperature should be specified in Celcius. Correlation is based on the CRC handbook.

equil_offset(obj, I_i)¶

Return the error in ionic strength.

Takes an ionic strength, then uses it to calculate a new ionic strength using the new equilibrum coefficents. find_equilibrium finds the root of this function.

find_equilibrium(obj)¶

Return the equilibrium ionic strength and pH.

Uses the newton’s method root finder from scipy.optimize to find the equilibrium pH and ionic strength of a solution, using the ionic-strength adjusted activity coefficients. This function is called when the object is initialized.

jovin()¶

Return the Jovin conservation function value of a solution.

Throw a warning if the ions are not univalent, or if water dissociation cannot be neglected.

kohlrausch(obj)¶

Return the Kohlrausch regulating function (KRF) value of a solution.

Throw a warning if the ions in the solution are not near fully ionized.

onsager_fuoss(obj)¶

Return the Onsager-Fuoss correction to the mobilities of ions.

This function returns a list of all corrected actual mobilities. These mobilities are automatically assigned to the correct ions when a solution is initialized.

transference(obj)¶

Return the fraction of charge carried by each of the ions as a list.

Should not precisely add to 1, because some charge is carried by protons and hydroxyls.

viscosity(obj, T=25)¶

Return the viscosity of water at the specified temperature.

The temperature should be specified in celcius. The function internally converts the temperature to Kelvin. Correlation is based on Fox and McDonald’s Intro to FLuid Mechanics, as implimented in STEEP.

zone_transfer(obj, vol)¶

Return the zone transfer charge of the solution at a given volume.

The volume of the solution is specified in liters.
